item.title: Trump Bets on Diplomacy Without Diplomats
item.description: President Trump’s most trusted envoys, Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner, are at the center of the Iran and Ukraine negotiations.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Nathan Howard for The New York Times
item.media:description: Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner in Israel last October.

item.title: U.S. and Iran Make ‘Good Progress’ in Geneva Talks, Foreign Minister Says
item.description: The Iranian minister, Abbas Araghchi, said both sides had agreed on a “set of guiding principles.” President Trump has called on Iran to make an immediate accord or face a possible U.S. attack.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Erika Solomon and Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:credit: Valentin Flauraud/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Talks on Russia-Ukraine War Enter 2nd Day in Geneva
item.description: The talks in Geneva, Switzerland, were expected to focus on Ukrainian-held territory in the east that Russia wants to control as the price of peace. Kyiv has said that demand is a nonstarter.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Harold Cunningham/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Russia’s top negotiator Vladimir Medinski leaving the Intercontinental hotel in Geneva on Tuesday.

item.title: Mamdani Threatens 9.5% Property Tax Increase if Wealth Tax Is Not Passed
item.description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani said his proposal to raise New York City property taxes was a “last resort” to close a budget gap.
item.dc:creator: Sally Goldenberg and Grace Ashford
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani delivered his preliminary budget plan on Tuesday.

item.title: Mamdani Ushers in a New Tradition: Ramadan in City Hall
item.description: Zohran Mamdani, New York City’s first Muslim mayor, will observe Ramadan as he runs the nation’s largest city, blending his faith into his public life.
item.dc:creator: Maya King
item.media:credit: Cindy Schultz for The New York Times
item.media:description: At a budget hearing at the New York State Capitol last week, Mayor Zohran Mamdani handed out dates to note the coming of Ramadan.

item.title: Colbert Slams Trump Administration After CBS Pulls Talarico Interview
item.description: Stephen Colbert said he had to drop an interview with James Talarico from his Monday broadcast because of new F.C.C. guidance that targeted political interviews on late-night shows.
item.dc:creator: John Koblin
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Michael Loccisano/Getty Images
item.media:description: Stephen Colbert was barred from airing an interview he had planned with State Representative James Talarico of Texas, a Democrat.

item.title: Jesse Jackson’s Death Arrives at a Crucial Moment for Black Political Power
item.description: There are more Black senators than ever before, but a major Supreme Court ruling could reduce Black representation in the House.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators outside the Supreme Court in October, during oral arguments in a case that could significantly weaken the Voting Rights Act.

item.title: How a Stray Quote of Jesse Jackson’s Led to a Rupture Between Black and Jewish Voters
item.description: The candidate’s reference to New York as “Hymietown” helped tank his 1984 presidential campaign and eroded a longstanding alliance.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Mahler
item.media:credit: Paul Sakuma/Associated Press

item.title: Jackson’s ‘Keep Hope Alive’ Speech in 1988 Was a Call for Social Justice and Unity
item.description: Though he didn’t win the Democratic nomination for president in either year, Jesse Jackson’s moving speeches at the conventions called on the party to care more about the marginalized.
item.dc:creator: James C. McKinley Jr. and Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: John Duricka/Associated Press

item.title: Jesse Jackson, Charismatic Champion of Civil Rights, Dies at 84
item.description: An impassioned orator, he was a moral and political force, forming a “rainbow coalition” of poor and working-class people and seeking the presidency. His mission, he said, was “to transform the mind of America.”
item.dc:creator: Peter Applebome
item.media:credit: Keith C. Meyers/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson acknowledged the applause of delegates at the 2000 Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles.

item.title: Six of 15 Skiers Caught in California Avalanche Near Lake Tahoe Are Rescued
item.description: Rescuers pulled six survivors from a remote California site where 15 backcountry skiers were caught in an avalanche, the authorities said. Nine others were still missing.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka, Nazaneen Ghaffar, Rylee Kirk and Francesca Regalado
item.media:credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images
item.media:description: Heavy rain fell in Altadena, Calif., on Monday. Some residents around Los Angeles have been urged to prepare to evacuate.

item.title: 4 Dead in Colorado Crash as Strong Winds Kick Up Wildfire Warnings
item.description: High winds were fueling the risk of wildfires across the Southwest and the Plains, and an Oklahoma town faced a mandatory evacuation. Officials said the weather had caused a deadly pileup in Colorado.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk
item.media:credit: Christian Murdock/The Gazette, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Emergency workers at the scene of a crash involving 30-plus vehicles, including six semi-trucks, on Interstate 25 south of Pueblo, Colo., on Tuesday.

item.title: The Sleepy Market for Japanese Government Bonds Is Now a ‘Battlefield’
item.description: Trading of Japanese government bonds, long considered moribund, is roaring back to life as fears of the country’s debt have sent yields surging.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis
item.media:credit: Naohiro Kimura/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Tokyo Stock Exchange in 1986. In the 1980s and 1990s, yields on Japanese government bonds shifted rapidly alongside fluctuations in Japan’s overall economy.

item.title: Trump Hails Japan’s First Batch of U.S. Investments
item.description: The deals, totaling $36 billion, were the first step in a $550 billion investment pledge aimed at securing tariff relief and sustaining U.S. relations.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis and Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi in Tokyo in October.

item.title: White House Shrugs Off Lutnick’s Epstein Ties
item.description: Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick has acknowledged traveling to Jeffrey Epstein’s island and meeting him on another occasion.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Yuri Gripas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Howard Lutnick, the commerce secretary, is among the Trump administration officials whose names appear in the Epstein files.

item.title: A Road Trip from Kandahar to Kabul on Highway 1 in Afghanistan
item.description: Life and business are back along a road once defined by war damage. But even with improved security, Afghans are desperate for jobs and development.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Tomás Munita
item.media:credit: Tomás Munita for The New York Times

item.title: Daniel Radcliffe on Returning to Broadway in ‘Every Brilliant Thing’
item.description: The Tony winner returns to the stage in “Every Brilliant Thing,” an interactive monologue with a message of hope “that might be vital for somebody to hear.”
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson and Lucia Bell-Epstein
item.media:description: “There’s a lot about this character that I relate to, both in the way that sadness hits them, and in the way that they find joy,” Radcliffe said.

item.title: Alberto Tomba Was an ’80s Icon. The Olympics Have Brought Him Back.
item.description: Nicknamed “Tomba la Bomba,” the Italian skier was a global superstar before he drifted from the limelight. Decades later, the Winter Games have given him a new platform.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alberto Tomba in the wine cellar at his home near Bologna, Italy, last month. An Olympic medal winner in the 1980s and ’90s, he is back in the limelight for the Milan-Cortina games.

item.title: California Wealth Tax Opponents Intensify Efforts Before Bernie Sanders Visit
item.description: The opponents’ latest moves include online ads tied to Gov. Gavin Newsom, a crypto-related push to raise money and competing ballot measures.
item.dc:creator: Laurel Rosenhall
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times; Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times

item.title: Potomac Sewage Spill Becomes Ecological Disaster and Political Fight
item.description: A D.C. utility had been working for weeks to repair a collapsed sewer line when the president blamed Maryland’s governor for the contamination on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Scott Dance, Maxine Joselow and Eric Niiler
item.media:credit: Andrew Leyden for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bypass pipes to move sewage around a broken section of the Potomac Interceptor pipe on Tuesday.

item.title: Height Surgery for Men Can Add Inches But Has Risks
item.description: Limb-lengthening can add inches to a person’s stature. But its risks have made it controversial.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Matthew Leifheit
item.media:credit: Matthew Leifheit for The New York Times
item.media:description: After his surgery, Mr. Trinh kept a meticulous log of his recovery that he shared on a Discord server dedicated to limb-lengthening.

item.title: Boneless Wings Are Still Wings, Judge Rules
item.description: A Chicago man filed a lawsuit in 2023 against Buffalo Wild Wings, arguing that it had engaged in false advertising of its boneless wings. A judge said the claim “has no meat on its bones.”
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.media:credit: Josh Haner/The New York Times
item.media:description: A reasonable person would understand that boneless wings are chicken nuggets coated in Buffalo sauce, a judge said on Tuesday.

item.title: Netanyahu Plays Trump and American Jews for Fools — Again
item.description: Netanyahu has gotten Trump to focus on Iran and ignore the destructive things Bibi is doing in Gaza, in the West Bank and inside Israel.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman
item.media:credit: Jonathan Ernst/Reuters

item.title: What the American Right Wants From Europe
item.description: The tensions in Marco Rubio’s trans-Atlantic vision.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat
item.media:credit: Illustration by Shannon Lin/The New York Times

item.title: Manhattan Hospital Ends Medical Treatment for Transgender Youth
item.description: NYU Langone Health cited the “current regulatory environment” in its decision to discontinue its gender medicine program for minors.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Goldstein
item.category: New York University Langone Medical Center
item.media:credit: GHI/UCG/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: NYU Langone Health in New York City had stopped accepting new patients into its transgender youth medicine program a year ago,

item.title: It’s Mardi Gras in New Orleans. This Year, the Party Might Be a Bit Greener.
item.description: Carnival can generate more than 1,000 tons of trash every year. A coalition of nonprofit groups, city officials and scientists has a plan to clean it up.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Delamatre

item.title: Shia LaBeouf Charged With Battery in New Orleans
item.description: The actor, known for his roles in “Transformers” and “Megalopolis,” was arrested early Tuesday after reportedly assaulting two people, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Valery Hache/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A representative for Shia LaBeouf did not immediately respond to a request for comment on Tuesday.

item.title: Peru Votes to Impeach President José Jerí
item.description: Peru’s Congress voted to impeach President José Jerí, four months after he replaced Dina Boluarte, who had also been removed from the presidency.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky and Mitra Taj
item.media:credit: Angela Ponce/Reuters
item.media:description: José Jerí was sworn in last October as interim president, replacing Dina Boluarte.
